Question 1 Let \(S=\left\{ x\in \mathbb{R} \mid x= 1- \frac{1}{n}, \ n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+} \right\} \cup \left\{1 \right\}.\) (6%) Is \(S\) closed? (6%) Is it compact? (6%) Is it convex? Related Definition or Theorem Definition 1 A set \(E \in \mathbb{R}^{k}\) is convex if \[\begin{align} \lambda x + (1 - \lambda) y \in E \end{align}\] where \(x\in E, y\in E,\) and \(\lambda \in [0,1]\). (Rudin and others 1964, 3:31) Definition 2 Let \(X\) be a metric space. \(E\) is bounded if there is a real number \(M\) and a point \(q\in X\) such that \(d\left( p,q \right) < M\) for all \(p\in E\). (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Definition 2.18 (i)) Theorem 1 A set \(S\) is open if and only if its complement \(S^C\) is closed. (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Theorem 2.23) Theorem 2 For any collection \(\left\{ G_\alpha \right\}\) of open sets, \(\bigcup_\alpha G_\alpha\) is open. (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Theorem 2.24 (i)) Theorem 3 (Heine-Borel Theorem) A set \(A \subset \mathbb{R}^n\) is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. (Marsden, Hoffman, and others 1993, 155 Theorem 3.2.1) Solution (a) We know \[\begin{align} S & = \left\{ x\in \mathbb{R} \mid x = 1 - \frac{1}{n}, n\in \mathbb{Z}^+ \right\} \cup \left\{1 \right\} \\ & = \left\{ 0, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{3}, \frac{3}{4}, \ldots, 1 \right\}. \end{align}\] (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} S^{C} & = \left( -\infty, 0 \right) \cup T \cup (1,\infty). \end{align}\] where \[\begin{align} T & = \bigcup_{n\in \mathbb{N}} \left( 1-\frac{1}{n}, 1-\frac{1}{n+1} \right). \end{align}\] (2%) By Theorem 2, \(S^C\) is open. (2%) By Theorem 1, \(S\) is closed. Solution (b) (2%) Take \(r = 2\). (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} S \subset B(0, r). \end{align}\] That is, \(S\) is bounded by Definition 2. (2%) By Theorem 3, \(S\) is compact. Solution (c) (3%) Let \[\begin{align} x_1 & = 0 \in S \\ x_2 & = \frac{1}{2} \in S \\ \theta & = \frac{1}{2} \in [0,1]. \end{align}\] (3%) Then, \[\begin{align} \theta x_1 + \left( 1-\theta \right) x_2 & = \frac{1}{2}\cdot 0 + \left( 1-\frac{1}{2} \right) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \\ & = \frac{1}{4} \notin S. \end{align}\] Thus, \(S\) is not convex by Definition 1. Question 2 (8%) Consider \(f: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\). Define \[\begin{align} U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) & =\{ x \mid f(x) \geq \overline{v} \} \end{align}\] where \(\overline{v} \in \mathbb{R}\). Show that \(U_f\left( \overline{v} \right)\) is a convex set for every \(\overline{v}\) if \[\begin{align} f\left( \theta x^a +(1-\theta) x^b \right) & \geq \theta f\left( x^a \right) + \left( 1-\theta \right) f\left( x^b \right) \end{align}\] for all \(x^a\) and \(x^b\) and for all \(\theta \in [0, 1]\). Solution (2%) Take \[\begin{align} x^a & \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(x^a) \geq \overline{v} \\ x^b & \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(x^b) \geq \overline{v}. \end{align}\] (2%) We get \[\begin{align} \theta f(x^a) + (1-\theta) f(x^b) & \geq \theta \overline{v} + (1-\theta) \overline{v} \\ & = \overline{v} \end{align}\] where \(\theta \in [0,1]\). (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} f\left( \theta x^a +(1-\theta) x^b \right) & \geq \theta f\left( x^a \right) + \left( 1-\theta \right) f\left( x^b \right) \\ & \geq \overline{v}. \end{align}\] (2%) Thus, \[\begin{align} \theta x^a + (1-\theta) x^b \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right). \end{align}\] That is, \(U_f \left( \overline{v} \right)\) is a convex set for every \(\overline{v}\).

Question 4 (6%) Consider \(f: [a, b] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\), and its derivatives exist at every point in \((a, b)\) and \(f\) continuous at both end points. Assume that \(f'(x) > 0\) for all \(x \in (a, b)\). Prove that \(f(b) > f(a)\). Related Definition or Theorem Theorem 5 (Mean Value Theorem) If \(f\) is a real continuous function on \([a,b]\) which is differentiable in \((a,b)\), then there is a point \(x\in (a,b)\) at which \[\begin{align} f(b) - f(a) = f'(x) (b - a). \end{align}\] (Rudin and others 1964, 3:108 Theorem 5.10) Solution (2%) By Theorem 5, there is \(x\in (a,b)\) such that \[\begin{align} f(b) - f(a) = f'(x) (b - a). \end{align}\] (2%) We know \(f'(x) > 0\); \(b > a\). (2%) Thus, \[\begin{align} f(b) - f(a) > 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(b) > f(a). \end{align}\] References

Question 5 Consider a function \(f: \mathbb{R}^3 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) as follows. \[\begin{align} f(x_1, x_2, x_3) & = \begin{cases} \frac{x_1 x_2 + x_3 ^2 }{x_1^2 + x_2^2 + 2x_3^2}, & \quad \mbox{if } (x_1, x_2, x_3) \neq (1,1,1) \\ 0, & \quad \mbox{if } (x_1, x_2, x_3) = (1,1,1). \end{cases} \end{align}\] (6%) Show that \(f\) is not continuous at \((1,1,1)\). (6%) Show that \(\frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2, x_3)}{\partial x_3}\) does not exist at \((1, 1, 1)\). Solution (a) (2%) Consider a sequence \(\{x_n\}\) with \[\begin{align} x_{in} = 1 + \frac{1}{n} \end{align}\] where \(x_n = (x_{1n}, x_{2n}, x_{3n})\) and \(i=1,2,3\). (2%) We know \[\begin{align} x_n \rightarrow (1,1,1) \end{align}\] as \(n \rightarrow \infty\). (2%) We find \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} f(x_n) & = \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} \frac{2\left( 1+\frac{1}{n} \right)^2}{4\left( 1+\frac{1}{n} \right)^2} = \frac{1}{2} \\ & \neq f(1,1,1) = 0. \end{align}\] Thus, \(f\) is not continuous at \((1,1,1)\). Solution (b) (6%) We find \[\begin{align} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_3}(1,1,1) & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{f(1,1,1+h) - f(1,1,1)}{h} \\ & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{1+(1+h)^2}{1+1+2(1+h)^2} - 0}{h} \\ & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2h} = \infty. \end{align}\] Thus, \(\frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2, x_3)}{\partial x_3}\) does not exist at \((1, 1, 1)\).

Question 6 Discuss why the following proofs are incorrect. (5%) Consider \(f: S \subset \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\), where \(S\) is an open set in \(\mathbb{R}\). Assume that \(f\) is continuous at a point \(c\) in \(S\) and that \(f(c) > 0\). Prove that there exists an open set \(U \subset S\), such that for all \(x \in U\), \(f(x) > 0\). Proof. Because \(f(c)\) is an interior point of \((0, \infty)\), there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \[\begin{align} B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \subset (0, \infty). \end{align}\] Because \(B\left(f(c), \delta \right)\) is an open set in \(\mathbb{R}\), its inverse image \(f^{-1}\left( B\left(f(c), \delta\right) \right)\) is open in \(S\). Therefore, we find an open set \(U = f^{-1}\left( B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \right)\) in \(S\) such that for all \(x \in f^{-1}\left( B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \right)\), \[\begin{align} f(x) \in B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \subset (0, \infty), \end{align}\] implying that \(f(x)>0\). (5%) Prove that if \(S_1\) and \(S_2\) are compact, then \(S_1+S_2\) is compact. Proof. Pick any sequence \(\{ z_n \}\) and \(z_n \in S_1 + S_2\) for all \(n\). We want to show that we can find a convergent subsequence of \(\{ z_n \}\) such that its limit \(z\) is in \(S_1 + S_2\). Because \(z_n \in S_1+S_2\), this implies that we can find a point \(x_n \in S_1\) and \(y_n \in S_2\) such that \(z_n = x_n + y_n\). Because \(S_1\) is compact, and \(\{x_n\}\) is a sequence in \(S_1\), we can find a convergent subsequence of \(\{x_n\}\), denoted by \(\{x_{k(n)} \}\) such that \[\begin{align} \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} x_{k(n)}=x \in S_1. \end{align}\] Because \(S_2\) is compact, and \(\{ y_n \}\) is a sequence in \(S_2\), this implies that its subsequence \(\{y_{k(n)} \}\) converges to a point \(y \in S_2\). Therefore, we find a subsequence \(\{z_{k(n)} \}\) converges to \(z = x + y\), and \(z \in S_1+S_2\), which completes that proof that \(S_1+S_2\) is compact. Related Definition or Theorem Theorem 6 A mapping \(f\) of a metric space \(X\) into a metric space \(Y\) is continuous on \(X\) if and only if \(f^{-1}(V)\) is open in \(X\) for every open set \(V\) in \(Y\). (Rudin and others 1964, 3:86 Theorem 4.8) Solution (a) (5%) To apply Theorem 6, \(f\) has to be continuous at every point in \(S\). Solution (b) (5%) The statement Because \(S_2\) is compact, and \(\{ y_n \}\) is a sequence in \(S_2\), this implies that its subsequence \(\{y_{k(n)} \}\) converges to a point \(y \in S_2\). is wrong. The convergent subsequences of \(x_n\) and \(y_n\) may have difference indices. References
